Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Hydrodynamic Theories of the Dynamics, Fluctuations, Boundaries, and Shapes of Flocks
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will develop the theory of "flocking": the collective, coherent motion of large numbers of organisms or biomolecules. This ubiquitous biological phenomenon occurs for organisms (flocks of birds, schools of fish), cells (collections of swimming bacteria, migration of cancer cells in tumors) and subcellular molecules (long molecules such as microtubules and actin filaments involved in the operation and reproduction of cells). The project will apply ideas originally developed for fluid dynamics (air flow over airplane wings, weather forecasting, and plumbing) to flocks.

This project will extend that approach to investigating what holds flocks together at their boundaries; to study the effects of birth and death of organisms or molecules (which is very important for molecules inside living cells, which are constantly created and destroyed as they move), and to compare predictions of the theory with experiments on diverse biological systems. Among these are experiments on the mitotic spindle, a spindle-shaped structure of long, rigid molecules called microtubules that forms inside cells when they divide, and which acts to separate the chromosomes into the two daughter cells. This work will also address flocks of organisms (such as birds and fish) to study their shapes and how those shapes fluctuate as the flock moves.

This work is strongly interdisciplinary and will advance condensed-matter physics, molecular biophysics, cellular biology, fluid mechanics, organismal biology, and medicine (through a deeper understanding of processes that impact cancer cell migration and wound healing). The proposed work will integrate research and learning by involving students and postdoctoral fellows in the research, and through the development of new course materials at CU-Boulder and the University of Oregon.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collective behaviors in active systems are ubiquitous in nature, especially in biological systems ranging from sub-cellular level (the mitotic spindle alignments during cell division), to cellular level (the multi-cellular wound healing process), and to the organism level (flocks of birds, schools of fish). How does long range order arise from short range interactions? How does such order persist in noisy environments? If and how are these collective behaviors in active systems different from the order-disorder transitions seen in physical system like the ferromagnetic transition in magnets? These are the general questions that motivate our study.

 

Instead of simulating the flocking dynamics using agent based discrete models, our project aims at developing a "hydrodynamic" theory to describe these behaviors. This hydrodynamic theory brings to the flocking problem an approach similar to the derivation of the Navier-Stokes equation for fluid dynamics: a system with an enormous number of constituent particles/organisms is coarse-grained in terms of continuum partial differential equations that govern coarse-grained fields (e.g., density and velocity). Then the detailed microscopic dynamics can be summarized in a few phenomenological parameters, which may be deduced from experiment or calculated from a microscopic model. Given the parameters, one can then predict the outcomes of experiments that probe long length and time scales by solving these continuum equations. One of the advantages of this approach is that biological systems on many different levels of organization can be studied using essentially the same equations, allowing universal behaviors, should they exist, be studied within the same model. This hydrodynamic theory approach, which we started 20 years ago, also brings a great deal of sophisticated techniques (such as renormalization group theory, dynamical systems theory) and deep knowledge (such as physics of phase transition) previously developed in equilibrium physical systems to bear on understanding and indeed discovering new collective phenomena in nonequilibrium active (living) systems.

 

During this project, we have extended this hydrodynamic theory to finite systems with boundaries to study the structure and dynamics of these finite flocks, and to flocks in inhomogeneous (random) media. These new developments of our general theory bring it closer to explain/understand collective behaviors in realistic systems.  In particular, we have systematically studied the structure and dynamics of finite flocks in low dimensions, and we have found some novel coherent structures (traveling packets and solitons) in the active systems in quasi-1D. We have also discovered some interesting structures, namely the vortex states, in our model in 2D. Another area we studied is how stationary (quenched) disorder affects the ordering (think of wildebeest grazing in a terrain with many random obstacles). The effect of quenched (frozen) orientational disorder on the collective motion of active particles is analyzed. We find that active polar systems are far more robust against quenched disorder than their equilibrium counterparts. In particular, long ranged order (i.e., the existence of a non-zero average velocity persists in the presence of quenched disorder even in spatial dimensions d=2, while it is destroyed even by arbitrarily weak disorder in d<=4 in equilibrium systems. Furthermore, in d=2, quasi long-ranged order (i.e., spatial velocity correlations that decay as a power law with distance) occurs when quenched disorder is present, in contrast to the short-ranged order that is all that can survive in equilibrium.  These predictions are borne out by simulations in both two and three dimensions.
